dc:description:
The relationship between *COX4I1* and primary mitochondrial disease was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of March 18, 2024. The *COX4I1* gene encodes an isoform of a subunit of cytochrome *c* oxidase (COX) that is more ubiquitously expressed than its other isoform *COX4I2*.

*COX4I1* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive primary mitochondrial disease in 2017 (PMID: 28766551) in a child from consanguineous parents with short stature, failure to thrive, normal development, and chromosome breakage studies overlapping with Fanconi anemia. Given the functional studies performed in this report (including COX deficiency on respiratory chain analysis with complementation studies), this Expert Panel elected to include this report in this current curation but noted that the Fanconi anemia phenotype is not typical of primary mitochondrial disorders. While various names have been given to the constellation of features seen in those with *COX4I1*-related disease, pathogenic variants in this gene cause a primary mitochondrial disease. Therefore, the *COX4I1* phenotype has been lumped into one disease entity according to the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Framework. Of note, *COX4I1* was first curated by this Expert Panel for its association with Leigh syndrome spectrum (LSS) on December 16, 2020 (SOP V7), with a final classification of Limited. This current curation for the association with primary mitochondrial disease includes the single case included in the LSS curation.

Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This included two homozygous variants, one missense, and one indel with functional evidence of mitochondrial dysfunction (c.303_304delinsTT; p.Lys101_Thr102delinsAsnSer). In addition to the case with Fanconi anemia, there is a case report of an infant with Leigh syndrome spectrum disorder (PMID: 31290619).

The mechanism of disease is loss of function. This gene-disease association is also supported by the known biochemical function of COX4I1 as a subunit of complex IV, as well as functional alteration in non-patient cells (PMIDs: 33672589, 33578848, 32075102).

This curation fell between Limited and Moderate. This Gene Curation Expert Panel (GCEP) elected to classify this gene-disease association as Limited given that the two reported cases are markedly different, and because the Fanconi anemia phenotype is not typical of primary mitochondrial disease leaving the possibility open that there is a separate genetic etiology in the first reported proband. No convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship.  This classification was approved by the NICHD/NINDS U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease GCEP on March 18, 2024 (SOP Version 10).
curationReasonDescription: The primary mitochondrial disease GCEP elected to score this gene-disease association as limited given the two reported cases are markedly different and given the Fanconi Anemia phenotype is not typical of primary mitochondrial disease and suggests potential for an additional etiology in the one proband. One additional case consistent with autosomal recessive primary mitochondrial disease would increase the scoring to moderate.

evidence.dc:description: Score 0.5 for reduced COX subunits and decreased amount of COX

MT-CO2 ~50% of parental cells line, similar results for COX5A and COX6C
In accordance with the quantification of the COX subunit contents (Figure 1C), the amount of the native COX complexes in the 4i1 and 4i2 KI cell lines corresponded to 54% and 61% of the COX level in parental HEK293, respectively.
In terms of maximal activity rates at 30 µM concentration of cytochrome c, 4i1 and 4i2 KI cell lines displayed equal values, corresponding to 55% and 52% of control HEK293 values, respectively (Figure 2A). But when normalized to COX2 content is comparable to parent cells
evidence.rdfs:label: Double knockout and subsequent Knock In of COX4I2 HEK293

evidence.dc:description:
COX Deficiency (20% of control)  in HFF shRNA line
OCR deficiency relatively mild so not scored

Showed knockdown of COX4I1 with shRNA in HFF line
Showed COX deficiency in HFF shRNA COX4I1 line compared to HFF with control vector 

basal and maximal OCRs and ATP-dependent OCRs in the HFF-shCOX4I1 cells were
decreased by 30–40%, but to a lesser extent than expected from the COX4I1 transcripts
evidence.rdfs:label: Non-patient fibroblasts shRNA knockdown

evidence.dc:description:
Score 0.5 points for western blot data showing absence of COX4I1 and numerous other subunits / with complementation restoration
Score 0.5 points for OCR deficiency and absence of response to uncoupler and inhibitors


Potential impact on global mitochondrial proteostasis is noted but not scored

COX4I1 and MT-CO2 were undetectable, COX5A and COX6C only barely detectable, and MT-CO1 significantly decreased in COX4I1 KO on western blot

Importantly, COX4I1 KO in HEK293 cells did not trigger expression of the alternative isoform COX4I2
(As we showed previously [15], HEK293 cells (wt) do not show detectable levels COX4I2 protein)

 Analysis of two technical replicates of two representative clones for each COX4I2 KO, COX4I1 KO, and COX4I1/4I2 KO yielded reliable data for nine cIV subunits (Figure 1d). These confirmed our previous findings of generalized cIV subunit deficiency in COX4I1 KO

Consistent with the profound decrease in cIV subunit levels, COX4I1 and COX4I1/4I2 KO clones showed complete absence of OXPHOS activity (OCR) or response to additions of uncoupler and inhibitors (Figure 2a).

Importantly, the respiratory OXPHOS impairment can be complemented by knock-in (KI) of either COX4I1 or COX4I2 isoforms of cIV subunit 4.

These pulse-chase experiments revealed that apart from the MT-ATP6 and MT-ATP8 components of cV, the majority of mtDNA-encoded OXPHOS subunits were synthesized less in COX4I1 KO and COX4I1/4I2 KO clones than in the wt HEK293 cells in the “pulse” samples
evidence.rdfs:label: HEK293 Cells COX4I1 Knockout

evidence.dc:description: >10 genes involved in complex IV assembly
All genes are either complex IV subunits or assembly factors associated with mitochondrial disease
evidence.rdfs:label: Numerous Complex IV subunits and assembly factors

evidence.dc:description: 0.1 (rare variant + WES) + 0.2 COX deficiency in fibroblasts (34% of control) + 0.4 (15% of control COX4I1 expression + No COX4 protein on Western) + 0.4 (complementation with wt COX4I1 with lentirvarl transduction which improved COX activity and ATP production.)

parents confirmed carriers

evidence.dc:description: Similar affected brother had COX deficieincy 27% of control (post CS correction) and carries both variants

evidence.rdfs:label: Pillai et al 2019, Proband
evidence.detectionMethod:
A homozygous c.454C>A (p.P152T) variant in COX4I1 was detected by trio whole exome sequencing in Patient 1 and confirmed by familial mutation testing in Patient 2. Unaffected sister did not have this variant. Parental testing confirmed carrier status in both parents.

Absent in gnomAD v4.0.0
